MemberSignature.Value: public static bool StartActivities (Android.Content.Context context, Android.Content.Intent[] intents);
.method public static hidebysig bool StartActivities(class Android.Content.Context context, class Android.Content.Intent[] intents) cil managed

Docs.param: Start activities using this activity as the starting context
Array of intents defining the activities that will be started. The element length-1 will correspond to the top activity on the resulting task stack.
Docs.summary: Start a set of activities as a synthesized task stack, if able.

remarks.para: Start a set of activities as a synthesized task stack, if able.

In API level 11 (Android 3.0/Honeycomb) the recommended conventions for app navigation using the back key changed. The back key's behavior is local to the current task and does not capture navigation across different tasks. Navigating across tasks and easily reaching the previous task is accomplished through the "recents" UI, accessible through the software-provided Recents key on the navigation or system bar. On devices with the older hardware button configuration the recents UI can be accessed with a long press on the Home key.

When crossing from one task stack to another post-Android 3.0, the application should synthesize a back stack/history for the new task so that the user may navigate out of the new task and back to the Launcher by repeated presses of the back key. Back key presses should not navigate across task stacks.
startActivities provides a mechanism for constructing a synthetic task stack of multiple activities. If the underlying API is not available on the system this method will return false.

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool StartActivities (Android.Content.Context context, Android.Content.Intent[] intents, Android.OS.Bundle options);
.method public static hidebysig bool StartActivities(class Android.Content.Context context, class Android.Content.Intent[] intents, class Android.OS.Bundle options) cil managed

Docs.param: Start activities using this activity as the starting context
Array of intents defining the activities that will be started. The element length-1 will correspond to the top activity on the resulting task stack.
Additional options for how the Activity should be started. See {@link android.content.Context#startActivity(Intent, Bundle)
Docs.summary: Start a set of activities as a synthesized task stack, if able.

remarks.para: Start a set of activities as a synthesized task stack, if able.

In API level 11 (Android 3.0/Honeycomb) the recommended conventions for app navigation using the back key changed. The back key's behavior is local to the current task and does not capture navigation across different tasks. Navigating across tasks and easily reaching the previous task is accomplished through the "recents" UI, accessible through the software-provided Recents key on the navigation or system bar. On devices with the older hardware button configuration the recents UI can be accessed with a long press on the Home key.

When crossing from one task stack to another post-Android 3.0, the application should synthesize a back stack/history for the new task so that the user may navigate out of the new task and back to the Launcher by repeated presses of the back key. Back key presses should not navigate across task stacks.
startActivities provides a mechanism for constructing a synthetic task stack of multiple activities. If the underlying API is not available on the system this method will return false.

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which contains the java.lang.Class JNI value corresponding to this type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control which jclass is provided to methods like .

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which provides the declaring type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control virtual vs. non virtual method dispatch against the underlying JNI object. When this property is equal to the declaring type, then virtual method invocation against the JNI object is performed; otherwise, we assume that the method was overridden by a derived type, and perform non-virtual methdo invocation.
